RATING: 9
Simple chess for people who don't like chess. Think the first player is too much? Then have both players deploy four pieces, with the queen being the fourth piece, then before playing further review the board and give the option to the second player to switch sides and become first player if he chooses. Other than the first player advantage complaint I've heard which might be valid, this game is excellent with no chance or randomness, fun and fast, the aesthetics are great, and the components are high quality.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros:
Enjoyable abstract game. Thinky chess-like play. Lovely tactile components. Can be played on any surface including the beach. No set up. Unique insect theme. 

Cons:
Always seems to come down to each player pinning the other's "arms" with ants for a large portion of the game. The game can sprawl in any direction, including off the edge of the table! 

N.B.
Hive was my favourite abstract for a while. Still a great game. Only ever play it now on Board Game Arena.

RATING: 6
A bit of a mixed bag this one.

Positives:
it's quick - you could play several games in twenty minutes
it looks good
it's portable (you could play it in a pub etc)
there is a fair bit of skill
kids can play it with adults
it's quick to learn
it's good for the price
it's quite fun

negatives:
the end seems to be obvious several turns ahead
some of the moves of both attack and defence seem a bit scripted
it's maybe too quick

I like it and am glad it's in my collection.  It has a few uses.  I don't think it's a classic.

RATING: 6
I used to think "Hive's a great game; but watch out:  it is definitely (at least it seems right now) attack-oriented."  Which made it not [i]her[/i] favorite game...  But we enjoyed it fairly often at first.

Unfortunately, now I think "Hive's a game with a cool idea, and cool pieces, and repetitive play based on abusing beetles and ants."  The depth looks to have gone away, mostly.  Maybe we're missing another level, but I sort of suspect we're not -- just slightly better tactics for getting the beetle and ant where they need to be for the kill.  Sigh.  Playing some with the AIs reinforces this belief.

UPDATE: My wife likes this one a fair bit. It's quick and pretty easy and luckless. I'm annoyed by the beetle blocking the queen ... --------------------------------------------------------

We messed up a rule that you can't place your pieces next to an opponent's, which is obviously a crucial rule.

I'm not much for abstracts and I didn't think my wife would be either, but the mechanisms for this one are really interesting. It feels like there's a pretty big decision space for a game this simple and quick.

The decision of when to introduce your powerful ants and how to use your less powerful spiders and such is pretty fascinating. I tend to "save" my big guns, while my wife will often bring ants out early.

One thing that bothered me was that in one game I was pretty obviously outplaying my opponent but all my pieces got locked except for a lone beetle. I was nearly just sitting there as she brought the rest of her pieces out and started descending on my queen. Fortunately, I was able to get my beetle to unblock some pieces that gave me a win. Obviously, an experienced player would avoid getting blocked like this, but I didn't like how that played out.

RATING: 6
Without doubt, Hive is a very clever design.  The requirement for a piece to remain connected is at the heart of the game, but the various bug movement abilities create interest also.  It certainly meets the goal of all abstracts; great strategic depth with a minimum of rules.  And yet.  

And yet, I don't enjoy playing it very much.  I think that my problem with Hive is the very incremental nature of victory.  I have to surround your bee with pieces; that takes multiple turns of incremental progress.  This is death by slow strangulation and I prefer games that at least have the potential for the quick rapier thrust.

My set had bakelite pieces and they were very nice indeed, a great improvement on wood blocks with labels.

RATING: 8.5
Initially, I was not to impressed.  But this game grows on you like, an insect hive on your house in the summer.  Part of me was worried about the potential limitations of not having a board, but after a few games, I figured out, Hive skillfully uses this disadvantage as part of its strategies. RATING: 8
For some times a did not dare to buy the games because it is a very abstract 2 player strategy game (like chess or go which are both not my pice of cake...).
But user Kaluga convinced me to try it out and I am glad he did!
Hive is a very enjoyable game, which is easy to teach and to play. It looks very interesting and the components are of great quality (both the full and the pocket version).
There are some nice expansions available (Ladybug and Mosquito which are already included in the Pocket version). The latest expansion is the Pillbug (got it from Essen 2013 for both versions). 
I am still a beginner and I believe a professional would play me in the ground but as long as the two player are of similar experience there is a lot of fun.
The setup time is extremely short (maybe 30 seconds). And it needs only 10 to 20 minutes to play it therefore it could be played several times in a row.
See also my comments for Hive Pocket the travel edition..
Plays count for both versions.

\_______GER_______/
Ich hatte lange einen großen Bogen um dieses Spiel gemacht, da ich dieses abstrakte Spiel zu sehr in der Nähe von Schach und Go gesehen hatte. Erst die massiven Empfehlungen von Kaluga hat mich dazu bewogen mir Hive zu kaufen. Und ich habe es nicht bereut:
Diese Reiseversion ist wirklich sehr schön, praktisch und vollständig. 
Die Stein sind nicht zu klein und leicht und können immer noch sicher im Freien zum Spielen verwendet werden. Durch das insgesamt geringe Gewicht und dem schönen Säcken kann man das Spiel überall mit hinnehmen (auch in den Urlaub oder zur Arbeit). Im Gegensatz zur großen Version sind in der Reiseversion schon der Marienkäfer und der Muskito enthalten.
Das Spiel spielt sich schnell (bisher 10 bis 15 Minuten). Die Regeln sind einfach. Und man kann schnell mit dem Spielen anfangen. Gegn Profis sieht man wahrscheinlich genau so alt aus wie beim Schach oder Go aber hier macht es mir nicht so viel aus, da ein Spiel sehr kurz ist. 
Was mir als Hive-Anfänger jedoch besonders Spaß macht ist das gemeinsame Erlernen des Spiels mit anderen Anfängern.

==2017-11-07==
Hive is a great game that I don't want to play.  The laborious consideration of each move for minutes and minutes makes the game drag on.  A single game of Hive (when played well) is very satisfying, but leaves me drained afterward.  I usually need at least a month before I'll even consider playing it again.

One user made a magnetic set to be hung on a wall, so that he and his SO could play-by-email the game.  That might be the best way to offset the analysis paralysis that this game requires.

==2018-01-30==
I actually really, really want to teach this game to (my future) children.  I don't know if I'd play this with my friends, but it seems like a great teaching tool.

I believe that I don't need any abstracts other than this.

RATING: 7.4
A modular chess game.  I like chess, so it makes sense I like this. Each insect has a specific move (just like chess) and the goal is to capture the opponent's queen bee (just like chess- no, there is no queen bee in chess, but you get the idea).  The only difference is the modular nature of the game (there is no board) and this makes it interesting enough to have both.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[i]Posted: 4/9/06, Rated: 9[/i]

Solid abstract game with a wonderful theme.  My sons love playing "the bug game," and they're getting pretty good at it, too!

The only drawback is understanding how the individual pieces actually move; the spider in particular is a bit tricky.  Fortunately [url=http://www.hivemania.com/]playing the free "virtual" game online [/url] (it's the full game for one player) helps in this respect.

Gameplay-wise, it's probably more like an "8," but I give the new version with the Bakelite tiles an extra point.  Think old-style [i][thing=2394]Dominoes[/thing][/i].  The tactile feel of the pieces, as well as the various paint colors for the different insects (and arachnid), really add to our enjoyment of this game.  A fun game that can be played on any flat surface, and portable to boot!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Love this game. My partner and I take the pocket version whenever we go on holiday or if we're spending a an afternoon in the pub. The bakelite playing pieces feel great in the hand and make a very satisfying noise when you empty them onto the table. We usually play with the three expansion pieces (ladybug, mosquito and pillbug) but the game plays well with or without them. There's plenty of depth and nuance to the strategy. We enjoy it so much that we've just got Hive Carbon for home play (with the larger pieces) and have bought Hive Pocket for several people as a present, all of whom have enjoyed it and others who have seen us play it have gone on to buy it.

Nothing else quite compares for 2 player strategy and portability. We even play it at a table in an in-pool bar, because it doesn't matter if the pieces get wet.

Highly recommended and the most played game in our collection.

RATING: 8
Sort of chess-lite. Enjoying so far. Love the clacktastic bakelite pieces.

My most interesting victory yet was my "string out the queen" victory. For some reason my opponent failed to see how to pin my queen from movement either by beetle or by forcing the one hive rule on her. So I just kept moving one step beyond whatever he put next to my queen and his piece together. This had the effect of stringing out my opponents pieces into a line that basically rendered them unplayable due to the one hive rule. It was just a matter of methodically rendering each of his pieces unplayable until I could buy the time to bring in my own pieces for the surround.

This strategy would probably not work on a more savvy opponent.

RATING: 7
Its very easy to get this to the table. (for an abstract game). The illustrations get people interested and the gameplay borrows enough from chess to give everyone a good entry point. The game has two problems, which keep it from being great. First the advantage for the starting player is tremendous. Sure the player, who got the advantage in the first turns, could mess up, but usually he just has to clean up.

RATING: 10
Don't just play this once or twice.  And don't think that the beetle is the only piece that can pin the queen bee.  And don't think that the queen bee is the only piece that can be pinned to gain big strategic advantages.

Do think that this is a short but very deep game for it's scope and length.  It's the kind of game where, after one or two plays you might think there's not enough to it, but after 4 or 5 or 12 more plays, you've found a dozen other ways of accomplishing things.

I've got the 3rd edition bakelite version.  So, it's perfect travel/bar game.

RATING: 10
I thought I didn't like abstract strategy games any more. I was wrong. This game is the very definition of elegant.It is simple, easy to teach, portable and it only takes 20 minutes to play. I can't think of another game that is so quick and yet has such great depth and replay value. I stopped playing chess some time ago. Thankfully, this game scratches a similar itch and is much easier to get on the table. Hive is one of my top 10 favorite games.

***Make sure to handicap yourself if you are more experienced than your opponent. Start with a big handicap and if they beat you, reduce your handicap a little.

RATING: 9
Giving it 9 as I would reserve a 10 for Go and Chess in abstract games

A month ago I had never heard of this game

Now I own my own set

Brilliant brilliant game that so far I can see no flaws in so long as one plays the Queen Bees after the 1st and before the 4th moves

The depth to the game is something that builds over time and the nature of the game is for offensive and defensive play to switch pretty fast

A player can thinks they are two steps from Victory

- only to discover they are the same from Defeat!

My only wonder is that this game is not better known outside the 'inner circle' of dedicated Gamers

Though like Alice this one should grow and grow in the years to come....

Note:

If you have no opponent then you can play solitaire by reversing all the pieces bar the Queens and draw them 'blind' for play

- makes for some interesting decisions and adds a bit of an edge to it

RATING: 7
3 plays:

An excellent, accessible game in the "pre-chess" vein. Just the right balance of complexity and simplicity to fully support everything from casual play by children to deep tactical study by adults.

The bug theme adds character to the pieces, so their movement rules feel less abstract. It's fun that every game starts out so simply but grows complex in a unique way.

There is a bit of a sense that the game is taxing to play, however; it doesn't quite have the sense of flow that, say, Jaipur has. In some ways I prefer Hey, That's My Fish!, which also balances tactics and simplicity, but which has more surprises along the way. In Hive, you seldom cheer, gasp or groan at a move.

Components are thick and satisfying, and it's a good game for travel (though the unpredictable growth of the board makes it tricky to fit on an airplane tray table).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Very surprised at how much depth this possesses.  I have been playing with various people and continuously winning, despite everybody trying completely different strategies.

Sometimes the game runs as a quick-surround and win game, where everything is offensive and someone wins one move ahead of the other.  This is usually the most boring of games.

Other times the game ends up having a multitude of moves, almost all of the tiles are locked into place, and the few remaining tiles must be manipulated to force your opponents hand into bad, but required, moves.

RATING: 6.5
Cambiado a Waltien en la BSK por un Warhammer invasión (junto a un Atlanteon y un Pingüinos y Cia), en Octubre de 2010

Habiendo jugado solo una partida, le doy un 6.5. No es suficiente para saber hasta qué punto puede dar de sí el juego. Es un juego abstracto en el que cada jugados dispone de varias fichas de cinco tipos posibles (saltamones, escarabajos, hormigas, abeja y araña). Cada tipo de ficha se mueve de una forma concreta. el objetivo del juego es conseguir rodear a la reina del contrario.  Es bastante abstracto.

Vendido por 14€ (junto con la expansión del mosquito) en un pack a christianlafferla de la BSK, en Mayo 2014

RATING: 4.5
I have played Hive more times in a row than any other game (with the possible exception of Magic). Hive is a simple, deep abstract game with a wide variety of strategies available to pursue. My rating is lower than the game deserves; after playing sixty times in a relatively short span of time, all with the same opponent, my play fell into a rut; I'm burned out and having trouble thinking about my moves.

With Hive more than most games, there is an astonishing difference between different people's styles of play. I use grasshoppers a lot; my fianceé loves beetles; Alex likes to freeze and unfreeze pieces. There are a lot of ways to play this game.

RATING: 6
Hive deserves the highest praise for its exemplary and compelling theme-mechanics matchup. Also the minimalistic elegance (no board) is a hallmark of originality. 

I believe both Chess players and those wary of the King's game can enjoy this design. A very fine tactical game.

My personal desire to play Hive however probably doesn't quite match my high esteem for this design since filler-type games fail to excite me as much as heavy eurogames or wargames. The BGG rating guidelines thus make rating decisions quite difficult. Anyway, 8 seems quite appropriate.

Update: A 6 more aptly describes me feeling about this game after repeated play. Just doesn't have the repeat draw for a rating of mine beyond that.

RATING: 7
This was a hard game for me to get into initially as I'm not a visual thinker. I really enjoy abstract strategy games, but I tend to favor those where pieces either don't move at all or all move in the same way as it's easier for me to "see" the moves better that way. Hive is more like chess, where each piece moves in a unique way.

But I have to say struggling through my first couple of games paid off and I ended up thoroughly enjoying it. My only complaint now is that when you play a bunch against the same opponent you fairly quickly reach a point where many games end in a stalemate.

Update: "Upgraded" to the Pocket edition as it was basically the same price as buying the two expansion pieces and I like the size better.

RATING: 7.5
Dry for me as I'm not really an abstract gamer, but Hive is solid. I'm not crazy about the default rules regarding the ants, though. But this game is solid with some variants.
   
We sometimes play where you have to have all tiles upside down. If you wantto play a new piece, you have to pick one at random and turn it right-side up to see what it is. 
This adds some randomness of course, but it takes the weight off of the players to 'play perfectly' and prevents a stale meta from developing. We prefer tactics to strategy in our games, so this simple variant makes the game much more enjoyable for us.


Ants made the game a little simple (they're very powerful, and using other units become less fun/interesting as a result), so we changed their mechanic so they can go around the board like usual, but they can only stop when they hit another ant (either team's ant). This makes the game much more interesting right there, and they become a fun yet still powerful unit, with interesting set-up and combo potential.

RATING: 10
Ok, I've done it. I finally gave a game a '10'. This is it.

EVERY time I play, I want to play again - without exception. It is elegant, smooth, and refined. There are other games I enjoy as much as this one, but this one scratches all the right parts when it comes to depth, accessibility, strategy, tactics and time spent.

Why is this better than Chess? I like that it is not as formal as chess. There is no board - it can be played anywhere. I like that it plays faster than chess (ok - not really - I lose at Chess really fast). 

Also, for an abstract, all of the pieces make thematic sense - their movement is intuitive and can be easily explained and remembered.

RATING: 8
I just got this in trade (San Juan) and I am really impressed by the glossy, sturdy, bright small box the game comes in.  The instructions look very well-designed as well, colorful and compact.  I thought the stickers would be weak at best, but they are quite thick, some sort of plastic material, and the backgrounds almost look reflective.  The artwork is colorful, and the overall feeling I get from the game is that somebody really cared about the way it was presented and did more than they really had to in order to get the best effect possible.  Hive feels like an heirloom game to me, so I'm going to varnish the visible wood at some point.  My kids are drawn to the pieces and like to pick them up and play with them as well.  I'm not disappointed in the slightest with the quality of this edition, although the bakelite is still tempting, even more so now that I've played the game (online).  I've had Zertz, and the impact of the pieces and theme, as well as having more of a feeling of control while playing, makes this more attractive in my opinion.

The game play is still delightful after about 15 plays (some of those online).  Unexpected things happen, I manage to lose in unique and stunning ways, and occasionally my dung beetles trudge over to the enemy queen and squat right on her.  Better than Zertz, better than Shear Panic.

RATING: 7

This game is not as brilliant as it is purported to be, and is certainly not the "new chess".

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I find Hive to be a curious title. One would be inclined to say that there cannot be much 'game' in two sets of 11 pieces with insects depicted on them. And after about 15 games, there remains a tiny nagging little voice in my head which does not succeed in making itself heard.

Hive is pleasantly simple enough, plays in a very short amount of time, and it sure isn't easy to win against a determined opponent... Subtle strategies started appearing the more and more I played against my main gaming partner. She dislikes hard thought and insects, but this combination actually meets her approval. Simple things like blocking dangerous pieces by attaching a lonely piece to them to they'd be held down by the 'no splitting the hive'-rule. The Beetle began to show its significant power more readily, and now forms a fixed ingredient in any of our games. Creating bypasses to free up much-needed tied-down pieces is an important tactic. Trying to separate the enemy Bee from her subjects so she makes for an easier target: present and accounted for. And so forth. The fact that you're learning the ropes of the game this way indicates to me that I'm dealing with a good game, namely one which allows you discover tricks on your own.

I think my main complaint is that to date I haven't been able to actually force a certain strategy to be succesful. Then again, Hive may not actually allow that, as the playing area can go in any direction when there's still a small number of stones on the table. But how and when you should add new stones remains a bit of a mystery to me. The balance between using specialty movements and bringing in fresh insects is a subtle one, highly dependent on what is already in play, and where. I'm hoping that more plays will help me (us) hone that talent so that I have a bit more sense of purpose than I have now. I'm not expecting this, really, but at the same time, when I look at how my tactics sense developed... This is not a game you should diss immediately after playing. And completely unrelated, its portability makes me wish for other games which were as durable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.86561
2008-04-19

A tactical game.

The differing pieces' movements remind me of chess, but they differ more greatly - the beetle and grasshopper specially having no analogues and taking some time to fully understand the capabilities of.

Thanks to the restrictions on movement or placement and the lack of starting pieces, analysis paralysis has never been a problem for me and I don't expect it to be.

Games only take a few minutes but still feel like a full experience.

I'm strongly considering buying this. I'll probably do so if I still enjoy it after the boardspace tournament.

2008-04-20 
(23 recorded plays - probably about 27 plays)

On Saturday, I played an overly long game that seemed to threaten to end in a stalemate. Though never repeating a 'loop' of actions, our pieces danced back and forth, with the meaning behind each move constantly diminishing until I won thanks to my opponent's mistake. 

I was worried that stalemates would be a real possibility and that play would be very repetitive, but having played a long game against thw 5th best boardspace player and losing, despite realising afterwards that I had at least two opportunities to win, gives me hope for the reverse.

The greatly variable playtime is an interesting factor. I think I prefer the more definite ending of other games - like Go, which will see roughly the same number of moves played on the same size of board.

Of course, Go is never as short as the shortest games of Hive...

8->8.24789

2009-04-21
35 plays

Another two supremely long games today.

I think I enjoyed the game more when it was over within around 10 minutes rather than taking over half an hour.

Towards the end, there was a long period when I felt little progression in the game. There was some change and my opponent did outplay me to snatch a win out of the jaws of a draw but getting there felt so slooow with little appreciable change in the gamestate.

Again, I'm reminded how much I enjoy the clear progression in Go.

I enjoyed this game when I was first getting to grips with it - it felt like a full experience could be had wihin a few minutes.

Now, I think I've reached a higher level and games I lose seem to drag on. 

I guess you could consider Hive to have a quick setup phase (lasting until both queens are deployed), a quick beginning phase (lasting until both queens are pinned), the mid-phase (as the insects are deployed) then the possibility of a long end-game (as the pieces dance around). Beginner games seem to be won before the midphase ends, whilst the end-game requires new strategies, more foresight and can last far longer than the rest of the game put together.

In this way, Hive mutates from a quick thing into a more drawn-out affair.

RATING: 8
- Gameplay and replayability: 4/4. Great strategy game without the risk of your head exploding; call it Chess-light.

- Luck factor: 4/4. There is no luck involved at all.

- Duration: 4/4. One game takes only 15 minutes, so you can play as long as you like.

- Player range: 2/4. Supports only 2 players.

- Theme and looks: 2/4. Although this is an abstract game, the insects map amazingly well onto their style of movement.

- Set up/clean up time: 4/4. Both can be done in less than a minute.

- Learning curve and documentation: 4/4. The rules can be explained in less than 5 minutes, and are so easy they don't need a lot of documentation. The manual is very clear, with helpful graphics showing the allowed movements and border cases.

- Durability: 4/4. I'm sure that my Hive set will outlast several generations after me. It would need a hammer and brute force to break.

- Portability: 4/4. The standard edition of Hive is not well suited for traveling because the blocks are really heavy. My carbon edition weighs 550g, and even 650g with the ladybug and the mosquito included! In comparison: Blokus To Go weighs only 320g. Thus, when you'll have to carry it on your back a lot, you'll think twice before packing it. I think this is a pity, because Hive has the potential of being the perfect travel game. However, apparently there now exists "Hive Pocket", which will most likely fix this issue. 

- Summary: Hive is fun and strategic and at the same time quick and easy on the brain. And as if that weren't enough, you can even take it with you on a trip.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hive is an interesting and beautiful game. I'm normally not that fond of abstract games but this one got me.

Each player has 11 hexagonal blocks with different insect on them (same setup for both players). One bee, two ants, two beetles, three grasshoppers and three spiders I think. The insects have different movement characteristics, the grasshopper jumps, the beetle crawls over things and can lock blocks and so on. A turn consist of either playing one of your blocks next to another of your blocks and not bordering an enemy block or moving an already placed block. You can't move blocks that leave insects cut off from the Hive, so if you have a chain of blocks you can "lock" a block by moving another block outside it and prolonging the chain of blocks for example. You win the game if the enemy bee is totally surrounded by blocks, not necessarily your blocks, any block is ok.

The game plays fast but you still need to think ahead, adapt to what the other players does and try not to get your blocks locked up. Really good!

THE BAKE-LITE VERSION!

I like the new polymer tiles and tile bag.  way to go, gen-four-two!  a must-own!

RATING: 10
Hive is either on my person or in my desk at work. I love breaking it out for a new person, especially when they confess themselves to be a fan of chess. Such an excellent 2-player abstract, with key moments defined by the rules of the game (in particular the Hive rule - when you opponent realizes they can't make that particular game-winning move because it would break the Hive, so satisfying.)

Expansion pieces are great: mosquito is by far my favorite for the amount of unexpected strategy it brings.

RATING: 9.25

RATING: 8
BoardSpace AI is much inferior to a human player, to the point where playing it may have been a hindrance in playing a human, not a help.

I enjoy how the weak pieces in this are all weak in interesting ways, and how none of them are simply lesser versions of another piece. It forces players to think about how to use weak pieces effectively much sooner than in many other abstracts and provides for more interesting tactics than most games with identical pieces.

Also, the bits are fantastic, at least in the resin edition. I haven't seen the wood ones.

RATING: 7
The german rules are very confusing. I had to use the english rules to understand the game. For example the german rule says "to win the game make the bee immobile" instead of "surround the bee completely". To make the bee immobile it is enough to surround the bee with 3 insects, because the bee can't be moved, if it moves another tile. Furthermore the german rules say "move a tile" instead of "move a tile sliding".

RATING: 9
(As of [b]20+[/b] plays) This perfectly fulfills my nascent two-player abstract strategy needs. The rules are easy to learn and easy to teach, and it plays relatively quickly. The strategy is varied enough to keep things fresh after several back-to-back plays, but not so obtuse as to make new players feel totally overwhelmed. I have successfully introduced this to people of various ages and gaming backgrounds.

[b]Why this is in my Top Ten:[/b] Hive provides the perfect casual two-player abstract strategy experience for those of us not willing to devote years to mastering the intricacies of Chess. It's [i]gorgeous[/i], which means it attracts positive attention both on the shelf and while being played, while its simple rules provide enough strategic depth while simultaneously allowing new players to genuinely compete with more experienced opponents.

[b]3 year verdict:[/b] Still my favorite abstract strategy game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Nowadays, I much prefer mitigable-risk games, such as Netrunner and RftG, but Hive has the timeless quality of Chess, which I played a lot in my youth, and it brings back the old pleasures of one-on-one perfect-information abstract games. (Although Hive is not abstract at all in my view.) It has a very peculiar crescendo of tension, because pieces are only added to the battle, never taken from it, something reminiscent of Go. What is unique to Hive is that the pieces ARE the board and so the topology of the game has a fluidity that no other game in the same genre presents. It is also a very sneaky game: I lost count of the positions where I was sure the game was over but the underdog discovered an escape route and turned the game around (always keep a grasshopper next to your queen). I believe people will be playing some version of Hive two hundred years from now.

RATING: 8
I was going to give the game a 7 due to the repetitive game ending scenarios I had seen during our last games.  However the rules clarification provided by whywai (thank you BTW), I now see that the game is probably much better this way.
My impression is that eventually playing styles will become a sort of metagaming in itself as not all the bugs are created equal; the beetle is vastly superior to the lowly spider;  the grasshopper can be very strong in the right context but ultimately the ant is really the one critter to look out for.  Yes, you win by surrounding the queen, but first bottling the ants is almost necessary before you can even think of nailing her down.  Excellent game.  Quick note on the pieces: they're lovely and neat but the finish could be improved so as to not stain so easily.

RATING: 10
For the purpose of disclosure, I own the carbon edition of the game, which includes the ladybug and mosquito. This game is the replacement for chess for me since it is much more accessible game. I love the quality of the tiles in the game and the fact that this game does not require a board at all and can be played on any surface. Fairly easy to learn and has enough depth for most people. No luck or randomness in this game and if you are looking for an abstract game, I highly recommend this game as no other games in this category come close to the tight design of this game. The only complaint of this game is that the pouch or bag that comes with it is not the best and makes the game feel a bit cheap. I would prefer something like a dice pouch. Some complained that this game can end up in a tie often but I have not played/mastered this game enough to run into that issue. If you have this issue you can play the "tournament rules" which should address some of this issue but I am not 100% sure.

RATING: 9
A simple design that requires some deep thinking.  I think it's pretty easy early on to see where you've screwed up, and at a certain point, you start to panic, knowing all you can do is react to your opponent's attacks rather than going on the offensive yourself.  Very important, I think, to get all your pieces out early.

How the hell do you get out of jams in this game if your opponent is one step ahead of you in surrounding the queen?

Teaching my grade two students how to play this game.  I think it will be great for their spatial sense.

The "beetle-on-top-of-queen" is a mighty powerful one...almost too powerful.  Does it ruin the flow of the game?  I'm not sure yet.

(wife rating: 10 [11 if it went that high!])

RATING: 8
Short and sweet game. Love the pieces, every game is different, it's portable, no set-up, rich in strategy. It is quite similar to chess but lighter and fresher. Always down for a quick game or two of hive. Make sure to get the version with the mosquito and ladybug.





UPDATE JULY 2013: Well after playing it over a year or so it's earned a permanent spot in my collection. It really is a great game and a lot of fun but there's a small annoyance. There's no way to challenge other pieces in this game. If there were a way to take pieces off of the board in the game or challenge other pieces to move it would open up a plethora of new strategies and much more depth. I've read about changing the Spider(most useless piece) to have the ability to either eat another bug and take it off the board or trade places with a bug. Sounds like a good idea in theory, I've still yet to try it out.

I've only played a handful of times, but I expect to continue enjoying this clever little puzzler for many years.

RATING: 1
I normally like games where you don't get to do things. But the bind Hive puts a novice player in isn't interesting or fun. It's just "bet you wish you'd played this 10 times already so you knew which obvious blunders to avoid".

I could easily imagine that if I got better at abstracts, I might come back to this and enjoy it. (If I avoid an obvious blunder when first playing a Euro game, it's not because I'm genius, it's because I've played similar games before.) On the other hand, I gave it a try because I *am* getting better at abstracts, and this one still feels the learning process would be an annoying slog.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has been here since the beginning of my dive into hobby boardgames. I've played this with everyone and in every situation, the game is tight and deep, and got tons of mileage out of the base set. That led to the italicised comments as we burnt out on the game. Tying each other multiple rounds in a row dropped the game down to a 7 for me at one point. 

However, I don't know that a night has gone by that this game hasn't at least been suggested by [b]someone[/b]. More often than not I'll start a game with people on time and the stragglers who show up late will play Hive while they wait for us to finish, sometimes ending up reluctant to stop. The only thing stopping this from hitting a 10 for me is that it's swung in and out of my personal favor, even if my friends wont shut up about it.

"[i]The base set made me feel as though there is little room for variation in openers, but very significant complexity to the mid game. The game tended to have conclusions which seem forgone from a few moves out though. Spiders feel overly weak.

Base game results in a tie more frequently than I would like, but is generally interesting. [/i]"

Expansions add so much, highly recommend them, bumping this up to an [-]8[/-] 9! with the expansions. Pillbug is especially essential, then Mosquito, then Ladybug could probably be done without. Chess clock is a good addition as well.

Have the Mosquito, Ladybug, and Pillbug

RATING: 8
Brilliant, tense little number. You're afraid to commit to each move in case you're signing your own death warrant. 

A few ambiguities in the rules (what happens when you cover the only opposing piece on the board with a Beetle - do they miss their turns until you've moved it?) mar things a little, but for the most part it works exceedingly well. 

I can imagine a pair of players both getting so good at it that every game turns into a drawn-out stalemate, but we're a long way off that level of play yet. A LONG way off.

RATING: 6.5
The perfect little filler for two, pretty much the successor of Chess in this departement in our household. We actually get to play this as well, unlike many longer games that suffer from what I guess could be called the baby syndrome (no time, no time!).

The game does have quite a bit of strategic depth to explore. That you don't lose your pieces doesn't mean they can't become useless - like when they're all trapped and you can't get the ones you really need. Trapping and counter-trapping all the time, the game goes to and fro, occasionally a queen makes a mad dash, and the shape of the hive changes all the time.

A very enjoyable game indeed.

RATING: 8
[2nd edition, Initial Impression: 8]
This portable and attractive little game is a near perfect take-anywhere light strategy exercise for two.  Each game has a feeling of depth, while only taking 15-30 minutes. The game is essentially a race to surround the opponent's queen bee.  The strategy mainly comes down to counting "moves to win" - when your opponent has fewer moves to win (the first player will always start out with fewer), your job is to slow them down while simultaneously providing mobility and flexibility for your pieces so that you can regain the lead in "moves to win". When you have fewer "moves to win", you need to find multiple moves that will provide the win so that your opponent can't successfully defend. The first-mover advantage seems to be only slight, in that the second player will have to play defensively in the beginning, but clever pinning of your opponent's pieces can provide a later advantage. It is fun to play around with different strategies and to see how the balance of your game can quickly change from defensive to offensive, or vice versa.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite abstract games. Player use their different insect tiles to form a hive (the playing area) and try to completely surround your opponents Queen Bee. This can be done using your or your opponents tiles. What makes this so fun is that each insect moves in the Hive in a different way. Grasshoppers can only jump, beetles crawl on top of the hive, spiders move quickly in spaces of three, ants can pretty much move anywhere, and queen bee's can only move one space at a time.

I like to use this as a good chess replacement because it really has the same idea of capturing your opponents most important piece. Though unlike chess, there is no removing pieces. Instead, good strategies involve a lot of blocking. That happens because there are two golden rules that cannot be broken: 1) You cannot break the Hive into more that one Hive. 2) You can never force a tile into a slot that it couldn't normally slide into.

The quality of the tiles is EXCELLENT! They're thick and heavy. There's nothing that could be improved.

RATING: 10
Second Edition

The components are among the highest tier in my collection and boost my rating way more than they should.  I burned myself out on the Java applet of Hive a while back but have recently been reinvigorated by playing face to face (it's a whole different game).  Hive is a more interesting and shorter version of Chess to me.  It's compact, simple, yet deep and engaging.  This along with Carc is probably one of my most played games, enjoying much love and attention.  It gets bonus points for being boardless and playable virtually anywhere with a flat surface.  My girlfriend and I often cart it along to restaurants while we wait for the meal or outside to enjoy in the sun on the grass.  What other games can you do that with?

RATING: 7
A nice light abstract that plays very fast with no AP and games are short and also addicting as well(very similiar to Pente in all these ways). A little more depth than first appears (kinda like clans) but not a whole lot, some strategy but its far more tactical, makes a good 2 player game for weeknights. I question the replay value here but the fact that its so portable makes it great for camping or the like. I'm not sure I would ever buy it (I have some games for this niche in my collection so it depends on price) but making it seems like a good option. Play online here to see if you like it against fairly strong AI: http://www.hivemania.com/vgame/

Update: 6.5 => 7 Slight rating increase, after a bunch more plays I still like it and I may have to pick it up. I still wonder if the first player has too much advantage but it is not every game for sure as I have played a couple neat games where momentum swung back and forth. Also, after some repeated plays you do tend to use the same 2 or 3 strategies so it doesn't have the breadth in strategies in something like Chess. It is a strategy game but it does feel more tactical as the board changes so drastically limited your effective planning to maybe 3 or 4 turns ahead and even then you often have to change your plan before that depending on the board, so it's not a Chess replacement but it makes a great fast and portable strategic filler. 

Update: 7 => 7.5 Aquired - Well some games do go simply along but wow some others really get swingy and take on a character of their own. The bee movement really can change the pace of the game and it becomes very crafty. The damn AI sure improved from when I played it last I think, the link changed too http://www.hivemania.com/play  I also bought this due to speed versus depth ratio and you literally can play the new version anywhere which I will be taking advantage of

Update: 7.5=>7 Hah back to 7. Well the limited depth is bothering me now, especially after playing chess a few times, games are taking on a certain pattern every game but at least it was good for a good 20 games, and you can't beat the versatility of literally playing anywhere!

RATING: 6
THIS COMMENT IS FOR THE GEN 42 EDITION.

2012-02-29

Initial Rating: 6.0 (September 2010)

I´m not sure why but I didn´t like Hive at the beginning, but as I played more, I came to realize that Hive was indeed a very clever design. It is a 100% skill game and one I lose often but now I can appreciate the game. Experience matters a lot in this game. The bits are really well made and the play time is very short. The rules are fairly simple but the game has an amazing and surprising depth, easy to learn hard to master :devil:.

I love the fact that the game is so portable so I´m always ready for a game of Hive.

Current Rating: 7.0

This is a quick strategic game that has one of the best and tightest themes I've played. 

I can totally see the hive invasion as depicted in the 1970's educational films I saw in Elementary school. 

This game is very portable, very fun, and kind of like a free form chess (it should appeal to strategists); it is fairly luck free really. 

So, it's highly reccommended and great for pubs and coffee houses. 

I do find it over priced, but I wanted to support the individual designer as I like the game. I have the first edition (wooden blocked) and to keep the stickers in place, I shellaced the wood.

I like the new bakelite version, but I'm not going to buy it until my version is wrecked. :)

Most people I teach to play will immediately play a second game with me once learning and seem to enjoy it for it's abstract mechanics and uniqueness. Highly recommend for picnics, traveling (planes not cars as you need flat, stable surfaces), and family events anything 10/10

I found myself desperately searching for the material (bakelite) and to see if it's possible to manufacture my own as I have MANY new bug ideas that would make the game really interesting without being OP or breaking it, but alas, it's made in labs, so I'll have to make due with the expansions that I bought! RATING: 9.5
Played it for about 3 hours straight... what can I say.. it's chess without the board. I feel it's a fantastic game and one that should be highly regarded, however, like chess, there is no random chance involved, so you need to match up to a relatively equal opponent or it wouldn't be a challenge or may feel insurmountable depending on which side you are on.

Things I love... many Strategies of offense/defense, calculated play, massive replayability, simple straight forward rules, learn in less than 5 minutes, and incredible critical thinking required to master, also if I do say so myself the pieces are of some of the highest quality resin I've seen in a board game. 

Things i don't like: 
First of all the graphics... I hate bugs... and my wife hates them more... this is the perfect game to whip out at a dinner table while traveling.. but that's a definite turn off... further the concept of a "Hive" makes perfect sense and I can't think of any alternative theme that would make sense... also the bugs provide the perfect platform to explain their mechanics and I don't see how that or the the "Hive" mechanic could be replaced.
Second, I haven't done enough research but I do not believe a third player would be possible... The game concept of surrounding the queen needs to be two players and alternating turns... it would be a huge disadvantage and bog down the game for more players. If there is a variation this would be awesome!
Lastly... The expansions should be included with the set upon update. they are quite expensive for what they are comparatively.

RATING: 5
Un juego similar al ajedrez pero sin tablero.

Cada tipo de pieza tiene sus propias reglas de movimiento pero tan sólo hay unas cuantas y sus reglas son bastante fácil de recordar. He dicho que no hay tablero, pero eso no es cierto del todo, todas las piezas tienen que estar conectadas formando una cadena que no se puede romper. Una partida consiste en rodear la reina del enemigo.

Considero que este juego es táctico ya que no se puede desarrollar una estrategia a largo plazo.

Si estás buscando un quemacerebros que se pueda jugar es un periodo de tiempo razonable, éste puede ser una opción.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2014
[/color][color=blue]
A chess-like game but without a board.

Each kind of piece has its own movement rules but there are only a few of them and its rules are very easy to remember. I said there is no board, but that's not really true, all pieces should be connected by forming a chain that can't be broken. A game consist in surrounding the enemy's bee.

I consider this game a tactic one because you can't develop a long term strategy.

If you are looking for a brainburner game that can be played in a reasonable period of time, this one can be an option.
[/color]

RATING: 10
I’m new to Hive and it amazed me. I was a Chess player with no opponents; too strong for my family and friends, too weak for AI and semipro players  at the club. This’s issea Chess replacementssw.         Set.  anyone can learn easily and we start at the same level SE with my wife and a friend. I know no other game of this depth in that size and price.  Portability and zero setup time are priceless. The Android version and BSA ensure I will always have an opponent for a quick game. The pieces are excellent checkers for droughts and mills and Pocket version costs as much as decent checkers set. Practically you get the game and bag for free!
What I don’t like? I don’t know, maybe the first player advantage, but the Pillbug is ordered and shipped. Draws are common in Chess too. Two players enjoy a draw when they know they played a good match. You don’t always have to kill your opponent, particularly if he is your wife or kid or friend. 
Alternative rules are possible and we could treat the tile sets as we treat a card or domino set, to play many different games. 28 tiles are the same with double 6 domino, they are enough, having in mind that they will always consist of two subsets. But we could always use two sets to 56, as much as a full card deck (with jokers, or mosquitoes) or a double 9 Domino. 
Overall it is ingenious and I just want to see how it stands the rest of time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Hive is my favorite abstract strategy game. It is a quick game and the rules are simple but the strategy and depth is great. It is actually reminiscent of Chess though I think Hive should appeal to a much wider audience (I don’t like Chess much myself). 

Like Chess, It has various pieces that have different movement abilities but the way in which the pieces move is generally much more intuitive. For example, grass hoppers jump and beetles crawl on top of things. Also, unlike in Chess, pieces can never be completely lost. They can be trapped but it is always theoretically possible to free them up again.

The most important difference from Chess though is that the decision tree is much less paralyzing (though still complex enough to be interesting). There is still plenty of room to gain advantage by planning ahead, but at any given time there are a fairly limited number of pieces that can actually move so it is much less brain burning to consider each of them. 

Finally, the game is also set apart by the unique mutating playing area caused by the fact that there is no board ... all pieces in play simply have to remain in contact with one or more other pieces in play. 

I’d highly recommend Hive to any fan of abstracts and I think it is even worth trying if you don’t like abstracts due to the various unique and thematic elements that set it apart from that category of games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hive is one of those pleasant surprises you find from time to time. I had been hearing of it for quite some time, but just didn't seem to grab my attention. Thankfully, I was able to give it a try when a friend and I were bored, waiting for the rest to appear, before our gaming session at our local game bar.

Pure abstracts tend to have a simple set of rules, deep mechanisms and zero luck. Hive is all this, while also keeping its length towards the short side. Obviously, it isn't nearly as deep as Go or Chess, but it's way apart from other so-called classics such as Checkers.

If two player abstracts is something you'd want to try, or you are already familiar with them and want a lighter one to fill a gap in your collection, grab Hive.

[size=12][b]Why I like Hive:[/b][/size]
+ I like how Hive has a theme (poor thematic ties are forgiven in regards to abstract strategy games). 
+ The game is easy to teach.
+ The game presents meaningful decisions.
+ The game has decent replayability, especially with all of the expansions.
+ There is high player involvement.
+ The game is short.

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Hive:[/b][/size]
/ Playing with somebody who is more experienced than you is less fun. You ought to play at a similar level.

RATING: 5
We like tactile games and the plastic pieces feel good and look like they last forever. It sure does look nice. my girlfriend does not like mosquitoes. Neither do i. So it never reaches the table. 

We added a house rule to draw randomly a tile from the bag, that decides who plays first given by the alphabetic order of the name of the bug (so ant goes before queen). then add the two together, they form the starting pieces. Draw the queen plus 2 more, You must play those 3 first. Then get the others. Makes life simpler and adds variety without any hassle.

I intend to keep it to show to friends and acquaintances and after that it may leave the house.

Not advisable for couples, but would be nice for parent/child game.

Of course if you get it, you MUST get the pocket hive version!

[u]Comments:[/u]

Hive is definitely my go to game to carry around when travelling as I usually know someone that would be willing to play a round, or two. It takes a just a game or two for new players to pick up and compete well against an experienced palyer. I highly recommend this for non-gaming partners as the components are almost as compelling as the gameplay to just about everyone.

RATING: 6
Solid abstract that doesn't feel like an abstract:  the movement is tied to what you'd imagine each bug would do.  The whole concept of the hive has beauty to it, and I love that the game is so portable.  

I don't feel that there's any kind of chess-like depth to the game, but browsing through some articles about the game on this site makes me reconsider.  

The major thing I dislike about it is that the Spider pieces seem tacked-on and poorly thought out.  It's basically just a very weak version of the Ant.  I wish the designer had come up with something more interesting for it to do.

UPDATE:  Been playing recently on Boardspace.net.   The Mosquito is a nice option, it adds a twist to the game and forces you to consider more possibilities during your look-ahead.  Good play seems to require using the "one hive" rule to limit your opponent's movement options.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.6
A lot of games try to reinvent the wheel, but few manage to succeed.  This is basically a very clever variant on chess, with some complications based on layout -- but chess just the same.  It tends to be a little divisive; some folks really like it and others hate it, based largely on how well-disposed they are to this style of strategic movement games in the first place.  I like them (although I'm not that good at them, so here we are!

It's a pretty nicely put-together game, with simple but iconic design and good, weighty pieces with a nice heft and texture but still portable.  Solid replay value, too, like any such game; there are some extensions available but I've never tried them.  I think it works pretty well on its own, so I'm satisfied.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There's a great game to be had here, it's just not for me.  It has a chess-like aspect to it as the ultimate goal is to surround your opponent's queen bee.  Each player has the same amount of insects/arachnids, each of which move uniquely.  Personally, I would much rather play chess over this game but this has a lighter feel and definitely takes less time to play.  It's also great to play outdoors (picnics, etc.) since the hex pieces are chunky and heavy.  The wind isn't going to blow them away!

RATING: 8
Generally, my wife does not like abstract games, and in particular more open-ended spatial games like Quoridor and Blokus failed to interest her. However, surprisingly she actually enjoyed Hive! Part of it, I think, is that she could focus on the individual pieces as in Chess. That somewhat narrowed down the spatial decision tree so she wasn't as overwhelmed. It's a short game and it's easy to get in a few rematches in. Plus, it's a great game to take with us since it's extremely portable and durable with the satisfyingly clackety tiles. The theme is just enough to help remember what most of the pieces do. All in all, even if you typically don't like abstract games, Hive is one to check out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Odd game, still haven't figured out how I feel about it.

Great icons, great pieces.  This is the one game that you can play anywhere including underwater.

I love each rule on how the pieces move.  It feels like there is a bit of theme in this abstract strategy game.  Much more theme than the average abstract, for sure.

You really have to learn how to defend from certain strategies, like when your opponent puts his beetle on your queen and then surrounds it.  That can feel like a bad experience once your realize, oh, there's nothing I can do to stop from winning.  But honestly, every abstract strategy game suffers from the same thing and I don't think it's necessarily a bad thing.  It's just something that you're either going to like abstract strategy games, or not.

RATING: 7
I have only played a few games with the Mosquito and Ladybug, but feel like they are very important to the game to not make it formulaic between experienced players (between newbies and an experienced player, the game develops very differently every time, and while the experienced player will almost always win, this adds a lot more variety). This is one of a few games I feel has enough depth for board gamers while still getting nongamers hooked very easily. Plus, it's portable and affordable.

EDIT: Beetle adds a whole new layer (both literally and figuratively) to this game once you know what you're doing, and breaks the maximum possible turn efficiency possible with the other pieces.

RATING: 8
A game with different insect tiles where you are trying to surround your opponents queen bee.  Each insect moves differently.  It is almost a blend between chess and dominoes.  It plays relatively quickly and is a much deeper game than it appears on the surface.  

It is a great game for coffee shops or the beach and traveling.  It is abstract and as long as you like those types of games, I strongly recommend it.  Also, it is a game that has a learning curve and has more layers that you know.

RATING: 8
A fun, quick-playing, abstractish game--'ish' because actually the theme is well tied into play, but in essence it is an abstract game.  It has the same feel as chess does in many ways, but I don't really care for chess and I like Hive.  That could simply be because I don't want to devote the time to chess to be really good at it and Hive is mostly played at a social rather than tournament level.  

Update:  Having played many games, including an online tournament, it is apparent that a draw can very nearly be forced by early play of the queen.  It is a pattern which, if not intentionally avoided, can wring much of the fun out of the game.  Further update:  The no-first-turn-queen-bee rule does pretty well correct the draw issue.

RATING: 5
"Hive", with its original rules, has a blatant draw problem if the starting player (or worse: both players) opens with the Queen-Bee.
In tournaments therefore this opening has been banned (and apparently the author John Yianni agrees with that).
In my view this new rule should become standard, since the previous version has nothing at all to commend it.
"Hive" is an original and rich game, and deserves to be played with the best rule set (in which case I would rate it a solid 7).

RATING: 9
My girlfriend and I play this constantly.  We were very skeptical about the theme... because really, bugs?  I'm not against insects, just seemed uninspiring.  

Turns out, it is extremely fun!  High replay value, short learning curve, but never feels easy to dominate.  Comparisons to chess seemed lofty when I first read them, but I think it's accurate.  We love this game, and the reasonable price and small size (we didn't get the travel-sized, but the regular Hive Carbon is small enough to take anywhere) make this a great purchase.  

After several months of ownership we are still playing and still loving it.  Zero regrets for buying this new.  And the Carbon version (comes with Mosquito and Ladybug expansions as of 2016 in Canada) is great. I thought the black and white (vs coloured) might be dull, but it isn't at all.  Happy Hiving :)

RATING: 7
Hive is a nice little 2 player abstract game.  In it players take turns placing pieces out into the play area.  The pieces depict various types of bugs.  Each bug has a unique movement ability.  The object of the game is to have your opponent's Queen Bee completely surrounded.

I like it.  The game plays pretty quickly.  The tiles are made of chunky Bakelite that feel good in the hand.  If you like abstract games, or want a fast playing 2 player game then check this one out.

RATING: 10
Hive is uncommonly good for an uncommon combination of reasons.  Tons written about its speed/complexity etc, but really ponder the greatness of a game so well manufactured that you don't have to worry about damaging the components!  Soapbox aside, the game is blazingly fast, but more importantly it is unlike other abstracts in that the game doesn't at all feel like one person slowly depleting another's units leading to that feeling of a slow, boring loss.  Hive is fast and fresh with a pace that builds to the finish, making you just want to play one more, one more, one more.  What's more, the variety of units and the modularity of the board and unit introduction make me think it will be a very long time before the game becomes centered on measured gambit style play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Use your bugs to move around the hive and surround your opponents queen.

Two-player only.

Pros: Really a simple game, takes a couple minutes to explain the rules and then off you go. After that there's plenty of nuances to the game left to explore. Portable. One of those games that's visually beautiful to play. And finally, this is probably the most appropriate theme ever pasted on an abstract. 

Cons: The replay will probably wain as one person becomes stronger and wins the majority of the time. The abstract nature of the game comes forward pretty quick and time of play may lengthen as it becomes a think fest. Not exactly a light game despite its pick-up and play aspects.

Other: The bake-lite version sounds nice and durable and is probably the preferable choice but I'm quite happy having the wood version to play and learn with (especially for a quarter of the price). If I happen to wear out the wood, then maybe it'll warrant a well-deserved upgrade.  

Best Use: Another nice quick 'game-break' type game that can be played over coffee or during lunch.

RATING: 7
01/24/2013:  This is an excellent 2P abstract where you each control a group insects trying to surround the opponent's Queen Bee.  There is no board, only thick, hefty tiles which, when played, form a kind of hive of bugs on the table.  There are five different insects, each of which have a different movement feature (as chess pieces).  I've only played this a couple of times so far, but there is some strong strategy involved.  If you enjoy 2P games, I think this is a must have with it's easy rule set, portability, awesome components, and lots of replayability as you learn the strategy of good play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I own the wooden edition. How odd to be addicted to bug-chess...
-----------------------

Here is why this game is so brilliant:
1) Depth without complexity
2) Short game length. Average games last ten minutes or so here.
3) Portability - Indeed I'd argue this is the consummate travel game. I've played this on airplanes, the beaches of Mexico, on a boat in the middle of the Ionian Sea, in hotel lobbies throughout Europe, by the poolside, and in the middle of the wilderness while camping and backpacking.

For a while I was concerned at the frequency of stalemate because of the first player advantage, but what I found is that there is a breaking point - I might play five or six games to stalemate, and then in the next games as a player tries to subvert the likelihood of stalemate, strategies mutate and there is a quick back and forth of victories.

Indeed this game gets played SO much (mostly at lunch or on the road while traveling) that I probably have at least another 30-40 unrecorded plays. It is and will remain my most played game.

RATING: 10

If you like two player, chess like games, this is the right thing for you.

spelgezel

A modern type of chess. Little bugs that are all trying to block the other's queen in their own way. Simple rules but oh so tactical! We have the pocket version which already includes the ladybug and the mosquito for the same price as the original.

The ladybug in particular is a plus in this game that seems so simple at first glance but that always brings you to the edge of your chair. Also nice that it's not really a 'board' game and that you can take it with you wherever you are (i.e. on holidays). One of the best abstract games for 2 players!  My wife doesn't like it that much as it is very cut throat and you need to master the moves of all bugs to play it well.

Camping?

RATING: 5
Hive made me discover that I have this unhealthy relationship with most abstract games, mostly born of petty considerations. I don't share the opinion of many people who express their dislike of abstracts (i.e. "the game is dry/soulless"); as a result I've probably restrained myself from saying (or thinking) that I don't get the appeal of a majority of them in order not to be mistaken for those critics, because that would send conflicting messages relatively to my gameplay-centric approach of board gaming. But the reality is that your average abstract game shares common characteristics that are off-putting to me:

- The game gets noticeably clearer as players get closer to the victory condition. Which is a nice way to say that the initial moves (or sometimes the setup) are very, very arbitrary rather than interesting.
- Because of that, one of the players (save high level) is randomly putting themselves into an eventually obvious disadvantage before actual play begins.
- Improving is about slowly learning to recognise turn/piece patterns of exponentially increasing size. That means no strategy until you you've practised larger and larger tactics for god knows how long.

So in all honesty, I will probably never own any part of the GIPF project, no matter how great they sound on the paper, nor become a decent Go, Chess or Shogi player. But if those games appeal to you, Hive is pretty, portable, short, accessible and looks as much undecipherable.

RATING: 10
Simply a perfect game. 

There are only a few rules which are very easy to explain to a new player. At the same time, the more you play, the more subtle strengths and potential mistakes which can hurt you in longer term you notice. Even though the game is simple, it's unlikely that a novice player will win with an experienced one.

There is no randomness whatsoever, so you are totally responsible for your decisions. However, each play is entirely different, even if you play many times with the same opponent. Probably it's because of insane number of possible openings. I don't think an average geek would (could?) memorize them, so it's a lot more fun when in a deterministic game like this you have to play intuitively.

Intuitive playing leads to another advantage, that is very quick pace of the game. Just compare it with chess, in which most players endlessly analyze the board for the best available option. It's definitely not like this. An entire play in Hive can be sometimes shorter than a single move in chess ;)

I also love the heavy bakelite tiles, which together with nice design makes them very satisfying to play with.

RATING: 8
Every GenCon I try to get a game for each of my two daughters.  In 2008 I went in seeking Hive and Diche luft auf die gruft.  I was in the sellers hall as soon as the doors opened on the first day, and low and behold I found Hive at Troll and Toad's booth.  However, I'm one of these people that like to line up all of their ducks before making a move.  You know, I wanted to locate everything I wanted and THEN do all of my purchasing.  Three hours later I was back at Toad and Troll and....no Hive.  I couldn't believe it, and their very knowledgeable boardgame rep doubted they'd have any more in, BUT he said he'd do his best.  Friday, no Hive.  Saturday morning, no Hive.  Saturday afternoon, and there it was.  Hoooray.

This game has been an instant hit with my girls, especially my younger (10).  She's a nature girl, and where her older sister gravitates towards games with exploration and / or confrontation, she gravitates toward meditative, organizational games.  Hive absolutely scratches that itch.  It is a "chessy" game, but one that has ZERO set up time, won't last beyond 30 minutes, and has an odd "mancala" like feel to it.  Tactile and carefree.

RATING: 8
My head hurts, but I like it...One of my favourite abstracts. It's fast yet fairly deep and it is the perfect travel and beach game.

Too slow for what it is - a fairly luck-driven card game. I do like the deck-building aspect, moreso than MtG - and I certainly appreciate that there's not hundreds of different cards with variable powers and possible combinations to learn and remember thus alleviating the thing I disliked with Magic that you needed to dedicate yourself immensly to the game if you at all wanted to compete. Dominion is a good game, and certainly a good gateway game - yet it falls short of a great card game - there's not enough control to be a great strategy game and not enough luck to be a great push your luck card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[b]Components: 5/5[/b] It comes with a bag to carry your pieces in to make them more mobile, the tiles are some of the best and sturdiest board game pieces I've ever encountered, and the bug drawings are clear enough that even the color blind can differentiate between each of the bugs without a hassle.

[b]Theme: 4/5[/b] Bugs are an interesting theme. Not really tried out much beyond a few games here or there, so it's enjoyable to see something somewhat refreshing from the same old farming, trading, zombie, or train games.

This is where my positive scorings end.

[b]Strategy: 1/5[/b] Maybe there's more to this game than I'm seeing, but my god this game seems shallow. I've tried looking at strategic discussion for this game in a desperate attempt to catch my interest and prove to me that I didn't waste the money I spent buying this game... Every single time I look into the discussion the same very few "strategic moves" are talked about every time I look into this game. I've tried my best to like this game. An abstract? A unique theme? This should've been right up my alley. This game is touted as "chess with bugs", which is honestly an insult to chess. I'm not really huge into chess, but what's presented in that game is far more interesting than what I've seen presented as strategic movements in this game. I doubt I've really looked very deeply into hive, but to be honest, if I'm not gonna enjoy the game after the amount of time I've already put into it, then I don't care. It didn't take long for me to be somewhat interested in chess, go, yinsh, tzaar, onitama, arimaa, Kamisado... basically most abstracts ever made that I've seen are ones that I would totally love to have in my collection. But this game is just so... flat. It's flat. And that's surprising because it'd seem like games where all the peices move the same, like all of the previously mentioned games besides Onitama and chess, would be flat and void of a lot of strategy, but they put this game in the absolute dirt in terms of actually being interesting.

If I was constantly outplayed and beaten in this game, I would certainly be inclined to look a bit more into it, but the problem is I’ve won every game i’ve played. One might say I could play a hive tournament, get beaten, and then try to delve into the strategy following a humiliating defeat. Unfortunately, no other abstract I’ve ever played required that kind if hand holding to hook me, so I seriously don’t care.

So, even if there is strategy in this game, I'm still giving it a one rating, because the strategy presented isn't interesting to me in the slightest.

[i][COLOR=#33CCFF]Final thoughts:[/COLOR]  That's it. I have other things to complain about, like the fact that I never feel any sense of satisfaction after a victory. Or that the game always seems to devolve into the one hive rule on the queen, or that it always seems to be a race to throw a beetle on the other queen and then jump the beetle off as the last action. Real freaking riveting. This is seriously one of the most overrated games of all time.[/i]

RATING: 8
[b]Hive[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8/10):[/COLOR]

[i]When I first got into the hobby I almost picked up a copy of Hive, but then played some abstracts I really didn't care for and wrote off abstracts as a whole. Over the last year I've played quite a few abstracts I've enjoyed and Hive's been added to the list.

Game play is a breeze to learn, but as is typical with most abstracts, actually playing well is the challenge, there is so much depth packed into so few rules and components. I was engrossed during each game and really enjoyed how it made me think. Components are top notch and after seeing both the pocket and full size version I definitely prefer the smaller set. 

I also recently played Tatsu, by the same designer, and both games are now on my wishlist even though I don't know how often they will get played. Hive has earned it's reputation as a great intro into modern abstract games.[/i]

RATING: 10
The version I played was Hive Carbon, which has a stark black and white color scheme I find very attractive.  The hexagonal tiles are nice and solid, with somewhat stylized, yet fairly realistically-rendered images of insects etched on them.  This is an easy game to learn to play, but a difficult one to master, I would imagine.  Each type of insect moves in a unique way, and must be  employed both offensively and defensively in a constantly changing configuration.  Much more complex than it looks!  UPDATE: I got myself a copy of Hive Pocket.  I prefer playing with the full-sized version, but this dandy travel-sized version is significantly smaller and lighter, so just the thing for taking along when you travel. (5+5)

RATING: 6
Clever design, beautiful wooden pieces, and a pleasant theme cast over what is basically an abstract movement game. Simple rules and easy to get started with, yet retains an ever-changing unfolding of movement. Plays quickly, so, good with kids, although they might find its abstract nature a bit dry--depends on the kid's personality. My son Trevor, who was 10 years old in 2009, rated this a 6. 

One other plus is that it's portable: my son, Trevor (who was 10 in 2009 and rated this game a 6) and I played a game at a restaurant while waiting for our order to come out. Also, with the thick wooden pieces, it's a game that can be played outdoors, as the pieces won't get moved by winds. 

In sum, for my son and me, on the whole this game didn't grab us, I guess because there seems to be a fun factor that's missing. But for people more geared toward abstracts with really nice wooden pieces, this game may prove intriguing.

Traded, November 2010.

RATING: 10
Hive is a truly outstanding game.  It takes a matter of a few minutes to learn the basics of the game.  Because there is no board, only the attractive Bakelite pieces, the game can be played anywhere one can find a flat surface.  The strategy, however, is not so easily mastered.  I'm sure others have said it, but the game plays like a simpler version of chess and it does have that sort of feel to it.  The short playing time is an added bonus that makes playing a "best out of 3" (or 5? or 7?) series a great way to enjoy the game and try different strategies.

This is easily the best investment I've made in my small game collection so far.

RATING: 7.9
First of all the theme (yes, an abstract with a theme) works great! The grass hopper jumps, the beatles can climb on other insects etc. This makes the game enjoyable and very easy to teach. 

Fantastic portability. The carrying bag looks and feels great. The pieces are extremely durable and elegant and you don't have to worry about spilling water or food over them. I play it on the beach! A great coloreful experience for everyone playing or watching.

The gameplay itslef takes some getting used to. There are so much potential strategies to follow and steps to count, that can put off inexperienced players. I got bored and played whatever felt right, without any plan. For me though, playing without a plan is completly boring. In kahuna for example your plan may suck, but you always have one.

I personally think everyone should avoid the carbon edition as the colour adds to the fun and makes it easier for everyone to distinquish between the various insects (especially usefull when playing with casual gamers).

The pocket version can be usefull and is a lot cheaper as it also contains two expansions, but then you choose to miss the great feel of holding the original tiles in your hands, it is less impressive to look at and the pouch is ugly. (Though the tiles are also colourfull and elegant).

It's sth different. Freshen up your collection!

(Wife's Point of View: I thought that the cute looks of it and the simplicity of the rules will make it up for the strategy needed. Failed miserably. She likes the components, she won't play it again)

RATING: 8
My favorite game for two and also my favorite pub/outdoors game. It is always in my car, ready to play.

Some people glaze over a bit at first. But through a patient "give and take" learning game, showing them how to effectively use the pieces, they usually really grow to like it. Only really negative reaction was from a closed-minded chess snob.

I've tried the "Blind Hive" variant (see variants) and found it very good!  A nice change to an already great game.

Using the "Blind Hive" variant is actually a good way to teach this game.  Two reasons-it forces experienced players into unfamiliar territory, leveling the playing field a bit. It also helps prevents new player AP. Flip it over, "This does what?" and then place it.  Helps reduce experienced player AP too. 

I've been playing new players like this: one game of blind hive to one game of regular. It is a really good mix.

I've played with the mosquito a few times, but it just does not feel the same. Instead of adding something, I think it detracts.

*Nostalgia-40th play outside at "Flicks on the Bricks", Portland Courthouse Square while waiting to watch Ghostbusters outside on the big screen July 08.

100th game 4/09.  After 100 plays, I feel like I am JUST starting to get this game. 

April 09-We were playing it on the dock when the Willamette River crashed a wake from a boat over on us. No impact to the game.

Any lesser game would have been instantly ruined.
