=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the better chess substitutes out there.  Hive can be taught in 10 minutes or less but is much deeper than it first appears.    There are some minor issues, such as first player advantage and frequent draws.  The first player advantage is no worse than it is in chess, really, and can be mitigated with the addition of the pillbug expansion.  Using the tournament opening of not allowing queen openings lessens the draw frequency.   A major difference with chess, other than the lack of a board, is that pieces are added to the field instead of captured and removed.  Once a piece is added, it is permanently in the field of play.  So the game becomes more complex as you progress whereas chess often simplifies to an endgame.  Games between beginners seem to focus exclusively on a race to surround the queen.  But once some defensive tactics are learned, positional play becomes a focus and the game really starts to shine.  Games can prompt great post game discussion like chess does.  Hive is without question a modern classic.

RATING: 7

There are lots of hard decisions right from the start on whether you want to try to go after your opponent's queen, or thwart their efforts to go after yours.

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Attractive & quick-playing game for 2 players where the pieces make the board as you go.

Given that I'm certainly no fan of chess, this is surprisingly enjoyable to play.

There is no luck involved and it can generate some of the same feelings as playing chess. However, there are much fewer options available so it doesn't strain the brain quite so much, and it can be played in a fraction of the time.

The pieces allow this to be played pretty much anywhere, although a smaller pocket-sized edition would be even better (with similar size pieces to something like Tantrix Pocket).

RATING: 8
[floatleft][ImageID=1054772][/floatleft]Hive is an abstract strategy game reminiscent of [thing=171][/thing]. Both players have the same composition of pieces and each piece has a distinct ability. Players must work to surround the opposing players Queen Bee. However, unlike chess pieces are added into the game on a players turn and no pieces are ever captured.  Hive plays quickly and the rules are wonderfully succinct. The beautiful bakelite pieces make it easy to bring and play Hive anywhere. Compared to other abstracts, Hive is very good but I'm not certain it can stand up against games like [thing=188][/thing], [thing=2065][/thing] or even [thing=171][/thing] itself.

RATING: N/A
A game I played a ton of when I first learned about these things, as it got a lot of love in those "what should I play with my wife?" recommendation threads. I did play it with her quite a bit, but evidently I have improved faster than she has and she no longer enjoys playing against me. I get very few opportunities to play this now, but I hang on to it since it's short and I have some idea of one day teaching my children how to play this. 

I enjoy spatial games and abstract games, and this one strikes a nice balance between each of those. Envisioning board positions that don't exist yet is a hard challenge in a lot of abstract games (chess, for me, is impossible), but I can manage it in Hive. The game also feels dynamic because of the way the playing area morphs. It's a satisfying game in a lot of ways, with a reasonable amount of lookahead.

RATING: 10
Pros:
* Our most portable game. The pieces are indestructible and the bag can be tossed into a backpack or purse. We took this one to a resort in Cancun and played it underwater in the swimming pool.
* In addition to being our most portable game, it also has the fastest setup time. There's nothing to shuffle and no board to setup. Just go.

Cons:
* This may not belong in the Con category, but it's important to consider. This is a perfect information, zero-luck game (like Chess). The stronger player will always win. Unfortunately, it's not a fun game to play suboptimally and it's hard to find the right balance when creating a handicap.

Neutral:
* The Pillbug and Beetle both have degenerate strategies. Get used to having to neutralize both in every game.
* We used to leave the Lady Bug and Mosquito out of the game a lot. Much of the advanced strategy in the game seems to revolve around doing something that causes the other player to lose pace. This might be creating a hard to fill spot around your Queen. It might be making it hard for your opponent to put new pieces on the board where she most wants to. It may be trapping pieces. Between the Lady Bug, Beetle, and Grasshopper (and Mosquito when copying those movement abilities), it was too easy to fill in gaps and then board would always end up being a cluster of pieces in the middle. Thanks to the Pillbug, the board may start out as a cluster, but it's going to get odd shaped quickly.

== 2014-05-04 - R:8 -> 10

And now up to a 10. The Pillbug breathed new life into this game (and then some!). This one has earned its 10.

Incidentally, we now always play with the spider able to move 1, 2 or 3 spaces and we play with all pieces in the game (prior to the Pillbug, we used to leave the Mosquito and Lady Bug out a lot).

== 2012-10-07 - R:9.5 -> 8

Was surprised and saddened to get a little burned out on this one. In a perfect information, zero luck game, when you play with the same person every time, maybe it just starts feeling the same every time.

== Original - R:9.5

This is our perfect game. We take it everywhere and can play it anywhere. Hive has inspired a search for other games that are portable, have very low setup time, can be played on a relatively small table, and could survive being played on a less than perfectly clean/dry surface.

While we have both of the expansions (Ladybug and Mosquito), we found the increase in the number of pieces that could fill gaps made it so the shape of the board was no longer as important. The strategy degraded into a more simple race and the first player advantage became too strong. We now mostly play without the expansions or only allow one or the other (sometimes giving the player a choice at any time of which one to use).

We've also played around with a few variants.

Variant #1: Start with all of the pieces upside down. This adds a luck element which is sometimes fun. When playing this way, the beetle does NOT change the color of the piece it covers.

We find the spiders to be annoying. Players will slide the piece around to count the three moves and tend to knock the pieces around. We've played with a few ideas to change the spider.

Spider Variants:
  1. Spiders may move 1, 2 or 3 spaces (this is our default rule now).
  2. In place of his normal turn, a player's spider may "bite" an opponent's piece. When he does this, the piece is returned to the opponent's stockpile. It may be returned to the board following the normal game rules. A piece may not be removed if it would cause a violation of the one hive rule. If the removed piece is the queen, it must be returned to the board on the next turn (we don't know why anyone would remove the opponent's queen, but we didn't see any reason to disallow it yet). [UNTESTED]
  3. Any piece touching a spider (of either color) moves as if it were a queen (including pieces which normally couldn't move this way, e.g. grasshoppers and ladybugs). Beetles may not climb on top of the hive when touching a spider, but if they are already on top, they are unaffected. Mosquitoes touching a spider do not gain the powers of the spider.

When playing with the increased spider powers, we usually only allow one spider per player to offset the increase in power.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like dominoes, this is a tile laying game.  Like chess, it's all strategy.  The rules are simple with a slight learning curve.  It's a very nice abstract strategy game.

The game pieces are very nice quality.  Even if you don't like the game, you'll love the quality of the tiles.

It's easy to rave about this game, because it really is great.  Play a few games online first.  It's easy to get hooked.  But I do have a few complaints:

I don't like the mechanic of laying hex tiles free form.  The tiles move around too much.  It's not like dominoes where it's easy to keep the game space neat.  Drop a grasshopper in a hole, then try to get him out without messing up the board.  The photos all show nice and neat games being played, but in reality, it's not so neat.  This was my experience.  Free form game board.  Nice idea.  Using hex pieces to achieve this.  Not so good.

I purchased the Carbon Edition of the game because I thought it would be nice to have the extra expansion pieces.  I find it better to play the base game without the expansions.  So if you buy this game without the expansion, don't feel like you're missing something.

I found the Mosquito to be a terrible addition to the game.  Horrible concept.  The Lady Bug, however, is much better.  The movement of the Lady Bug should have been what the Spider is.  I always thought the Spider was a bit wonky.  The Spider is the hardest piece to plan movement because it's not so easy to count spaces around the outside of the board.  The Lady Bug movement is a much better idea.  That's my feelings.  This game should not have introduced expansions.  Instead, it should have revised the movement of the Spider to be like the Lady Bug and left the rest alone.

RATING: 8
I played this game in two bursts.  When I first got it, I played it probably 15 times with my girlfriend of the time.  Then it sat there dormant until a friend was over and asked about it, and I played again for a few times.  In both cases, I really enjoyed the last few games we played, as the earlier easy paths to victory were being dealt with by my opponents and I was forced to get a bit more creative.

One thing I've noticed with both players is that they don't manage the potential of my queen moving very well at first, allowing me to lock pieces in by stringing them along.  They eventually learn to "trap *then* surround" and the games get much better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.4
Players: 2
Time: 10-20 min.

Each player has the same set of pieces: 1 queen bee, 2 spiders, 2 beetles, 3 ants, and 3 grasshoppers. Similar to pieces in chess, each piece moves differently and may be more useful at different stages of the game. To win, trap the other player's queen bee (similar to checkmating the king in chess). The rules are quite simple once you've learned how the different pieces move.

RATING: 7
This deserves at least a 7 just for being a 2-player abstract that my wife likes and will play with me!

In fact, she's normally the one who asks to play - and of course I'll usually happily accept. While sometimes one of us wins quickly, most of the time the games go on for a while and can lead to really interesting endgame positions, where one of us (usually me) overlooks that what we thought was the winning move creates a key connection allowing a long-pinned piece to move. In fact, quite often in this game I get a winning position early on but mess up in this or similar fashion, and tend to end up with a hopeless game. But such situations make the game really quite interesting, and it isn't always just down to my stupidity :)

I should note that these comments were written a couple of years ago, it's now been quite a while since we played Hive or either of us asked to play it. Definitely a good game, but not one I've ever been very excited to play.

RATING: 6
So far I've played this game online only, at http://www.hivemania.com.  It's a very clever game.  To me this is in many ways like a lighter version of chess.  Lighter because it's quicker and less brain-burning.  Similar because of the special movement abilitites of the pieces, the way you have to plan ahead, and the way that you can put your opponent's queen in what is essentially a "check" or "checkmate" situation.  It is also similar to chess in that stalemates are definitely possible, especially if players are evenly matched.  So I would say if you enjoy chess but want something lighter and quicker, this is an excellent choice.  If you really, really hate chess, then I can't imagine you enjoying this game for very long.

RATING: 10
Hive is a surprisingly deep strategy game. Surprisingly, since the rules are really simple, and easy to be picked up by players of any level. The often quoted "bakelite-goodness" of the tiles, which come in easy-on-the hand, heavy, polymer hexagonal discs, give this game a special feel that lifts it above other products in the burgeoning market of strategy boardgames. And, of course, the animals are pretty insects, allowing players to treat these insects as strategic assets rather than pests.
(I'm not kidding, I LOVE these insects, one of the few games that allows kids to get closely acquainted with insects, and nip arachnophobia in the bud right away - hmm, then again, those spiders ARE the weakest pawns.... ;-)

RATING: 6
I've played Hive both online against the computer and against live players (in person). It has been compared to Chess, in that different pieces have unique ways of moving, etc. But it does not "feel" at all like Chess to me. I don't particularly care for Chess, but I enjoy Hive. The insect theme is a winner for me, as is the way that placement of various insects "creates" the playing field. It's a mechanic I really dig, and meshes well with both the theme and the other mechanics of the game. Unfortunately, repeated plays have seen the endgame bog down into a dance (not unlike the dance of a honey bee sharing news of a nectar discovery with its hive-mates) of positioning which causes the game to drag on and on.

RATING: 8.297
It's a sometime obsession.  You can play it for free at http://www.hivemania.com/vgame or http://www.boardspace.net  It's sort of a cross between chess and tic-tac-toe with a bug puzzle hex theme.  I say tic-tac-toe because you can lose, I mean play, the game really fast.  It's an interesting time killer, but the computer AI at www.hivemania.com seems almost impossible to beat in the beginning.  It seems a lot harder than Blokus, but it's also a lot faster.  Compared to chess, I think players are more often of similar skill for a game like hive.  I've never played it except on the computer.  However, I think it might be somewhat confusing to remember what pieces can't move in certain locations without computer guidance.

RATING: 5
[2011-01-23]

Nagyon erős absztrakt játék két személynek. Olyannyira erős, hogy sakkhoz is hasonlítják nem véletlenül. Nekem ez már annyira absztrakt és száraz, hogy nem is nevezném játéknak. Ahogyan a sakk is, számomra ez sem játékkategória már. Nem az a játék, amire azt mondom, hogy kikapcsol és szórakoztat. Itt keményen kell gondolkodni és erőltetni az agyat. A pontszám sokkal nagyobb lenne részemről, ha magát az ötletet és a megvalósítást értékelném, de mivel a szórakozás, kikapcsolódás is része a játéknak, így nem tudok ennél jó szívvel több pontot adni.
A játék kivitelezése tökéletes, gyönyörűek a kövek, fantasztikus, hogy utazó szütyő is jár a játékhoz a dobozban, amivel könnyedén lehet vinni hosszabb utakra is. Profi!

I'd wanted to try Hive for some time before I finally played it, and then I played it several times against a few different opponents. I wasn't expecting to like it as much as I did, nor was I expecting it to see as much table time in such a short time. I especially like the decisions between unit deployment and positioning, the wisdom of which are not at all obvious. Unlike abstracts with fixed setups, games begin (and not just end) differently. It may not be the deepest abstract around, but it's quick, satisfying, and popular with diverse groups of people. The durable pieces make it a great pub game.

RATING: 6
It's an abstract using hexes labeled with various bugs. On your turn, you either add a piece to the play area (must be adjacent to one of your pieces but not touching opponent) or move a piece. The goal is to completely surround your opponent's queen. Each piece moves in different ways (grasshoppers jump in a line, ants crawl along edges any distance, spiders crawl along edges up to 3 spaces, beetle moves to 1 adjacent space and can climb on top of other pieces, queen moves 1 space).

RATING: 8
Whether it's fair or not, I'm going to compare this game to "Hey! That's my fish!" (henceforth referred to as HtmF), because my main reason for picking up Hive was the truly shocking degree of fun I've had with HtmF.  And while I was impressed with the game of "Hive" over-all, it didn't quite hit the same sweet spot as HtmF (and it's not just because I have an extreme aversion to insects in general!).  That's not to say it isn't a fun game and doesn't have a lot going for it (such as it's portability and indestructability), because it is and it does.  In fact, one thing that I loved about it was the fact that my wife (who is generally less strategically-minded than myself) cleaned my clock the first few times we played this.  I do love a challenge, and I also love a simple, strategic, lovely-looking game, which is exactly what Hive is.  And best of all, you can play this game on a table at a pub without worrying about the slimy, spilled beer stickiness ruining the components.  Game design: 5/5  Personal enjoyment: 3/5  Total: 8/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Interesting but limited tile-laying abstract game. Each player has as an equal number of tiles depicting various different arthropods and each of these can move in different ways e.g. the beetle can be placed on top of other tiles, the grasshopper can jump over other tiles, the soldier ant can be placed anywhere on the outside of the 'hive' (the group of tiles). The object is to completely surround your opponent's queen bee so that it cannot move. The variety brought to the game by the way the tiles move and the tactical decisions that brings is a definite plus point, but overall the game begins to feel repetitive all too quickly on account of the single object goal.

Would rate it a 9.5 as a kids game: no text involved (great for my kid as he can't yet read), simple rules (just 4 small pages), playing pieces that can withstand falling off the table and ultra portable if you put the playing pieces + small rules in a chits-bag.

If it wasn't for some 'difficult' to explain rules (no movement of other pieces during moves, no placing in or out a surrounded spot) I would rate this a perfect 10 as a kids game.

Stimulates thinking ahead, thinking creatively and the bug-theme even supports the game play.

Great small game. Definitely recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hive is a short, simple, and interesting game. I love the little details and strategies--when to place which insect, when to introduce the queen. The component tiles are well manufactured, though I had to clean some white residue off the black pieces that built up as they had been stored under the white pieces for quite some time in the box.

My sister and I quite enjoy the game and can squeeze two or three games in a half hour space of free time. I can't wait to teach my friends back at college. This is a fantastic game for people on the go with a hankering for strategy.

RATING: 10

Hive, more than any other game I have tried, has the potential to still be around in 100 years. It feels like Chess, except I am around when it was created.

I am by no means a hive expert. But the last time I played a serious round of games with my brother I won 10 out of 13 games. We haven't played since. And my wife bought me a hive t-shirt to make up for not playing it with me anymore.
Like chess, the game is almost too great.

RATING: 5
I have played it couple of times. I had a lot of fun, the game is both challenging and quick which i understand as virtues for this kind of games. Excellent introduction to gaming for young person. For the older gamers the problem with this branch of games is always the same: we play the rules, the rest is just decoration. It is "the game" per se. Nothing more, so it will become more and more "empty" and disappointing as we better understand and see where are the borders of its rules (which are simultaneously the borders of game, since it offers nothing to imagination). But the idea, the rules are still well designed. One of the best games i have played and would be willing to play it once again if i had an occasion.

RATING: 7
This is a cute little two player strategy game where you are trying to capture the opponent's queen bee. Simple to learn, highly portable (comes in a pouch), and only requires a flat surface to play.  This game is similar to  chess in that all the pieces have unique ways of moving, requiring multiple levels of planning in advance to ultimately capture the enemy queen by completely surrounding it with your hexagonal creepy crawlies.

RATING: 8.5
I can't see a flaw to not be a perfect 10. Chess for the new millenium. A classic. kudos to the developer for balance, depth and originality.

The Carbon set actually improves aesthetic of game, by going with classy B&W instead of the rather garish, little kid's game coloured tiles.

Both Mosquito and Ladybug fit nicely and for me are just part of Hive now, not to be played with expansions included.

UPDATE 11/05/2011

Have played a lot lately and have dropped my rating by 2. Once you get behind in terms of Queen being surrounded, you are almost always doomed, since no way to free a queen under a bettle, or surrounded on three sides.

That means often you finish games knowing outcome.

RATING: 8
I love Hive! It's such a simple and elegant two-player design. (I don't even mind the spiders as much as I thought I would!) What I've noticed in my plays against my husband is that one of us will tend to win a block of games with one strategy until the other figures out a strategy to beat it, so it makes for a really addictive challenge. It's quite a victorious feeling when you finally "break" the other player's strategy. The other awesome advantage to Hive is that it is extremely quick and portable--you can play it nearly anywhere. The quality of the pieces is exceptional, as well. Overall, a very lovely game.

RATING: 10
Hive is an abstract two player strategy game with the theme and mechanics centered off of a insect hive. Each piece has a particular move like in chess, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. I really enjoy that the game is made of heavy duty domino like tiles that are thick and robust. The game comes in a portable bag to play on the go and can be played almost anywhere you have a flat surface. I prefer the color pieces to the Carbon version which drabs out the game. The game is easy to learn, difficult to master against a skilled opponent. Games can be short but with the right opponent can become drawn out to about 30 minutes at most in my experience. The game can be downloaded off of Steam which the AI provides a skilled player with a challenge, sometimes a brutal undertaking. Hive will remain in my collection definitely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

I like the fact that each insect (and the spider, which technically isn't an insect) has its own rules, which gives it a chess-like feel, and how you have to use all these different abilities to get closer to the enemy queen and corner her.

RATING: 6.5
I waited for a long time before purchasing Hive. My wife and I love a solid two-player game. But neither of us love abstracts. After considering Hive for several months. I bought it before we took off for an anniversary vacation to Greece. We played it a few times and we could both see why it's enjoyed by many. But it wasn't really our cup of tea.

The game is probably best described as Chess Lite. It's incredibly tactical, and once players are good at it, it becomes an exercise in mind reading, and counter play to infinite consideration. Like I said, awesome for some, not so much for me and my wife. I rate it a 6 after three plays.

RATING: 7
Neat little near-abstract with room for creativity and depth.... It's not as deep as some other abstracts I prefer, though. It's more chess-like than go-like, in the sense that moves are more likely to be 'lots' better than other ones, and that missing a particular rejoinder is more likely to cost you; whereas Go is (mostly) a subtle build-up of long-term advantage.

RATING: 7.5
Quick, simple, but surprisely deep, few tiles but many strategies inside, great replayability, you can play it seriously (brainburning) or very quickly (both ways are fun!), bugs with lovely looking, my girlfriend hates traditional abstracts (chess, go..) but loves this... all of this make it my favourite abstract by far. White encourages aggresive playing during open-mid play, black defending, but each game is so quick that you can play 3-4 games (changing colors) in the same time you play one chess game...I'd never thought an abstract could be so enjoyable!

However, Hive also exhibits some of the problems inherent in the form, with the first player advantage being a bit too strong and the game being a bit too prone to repetitive move stalemates among experienced players.

Worth exploring, though.  The chunky pieces are much better than the pasted on foil ones that were difficult to see in poor light.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pros: highly tactical, no luck, near-perfect information, easy to learn but hard to master, substantial theme for an abstract game

Cons: steeper learning curve to attain victory, can be played to stalemate, can outstay its welcome, possibly unbalanced in favor of the player going first

I'm terrible at abstract strategy, but I'm a glutton for punishment so I still play this--my abstract of choice. Good fun, elegant design, and tons of depth! Perhaps the most interesting aspect of this as compared to other abstract strategy games is the geometry of the "hive" you're building and the "freedom to move" rule that is so beautifully elegant. That and that you get to choose which pieces you put into play makes for meaningful decision-making that dictates your strategy, as well as a significantly different game experience each time.

Plays listed may include the Ladybug and Mosquito expansions. I have not tried others. Besides online play, I've mostly played Hive Carbon and Hive Pocket implementations.

RATING: 6
Oct 2017:
When I first started looking into games (before I realized just how many are out there), I was looking for 2P games for my fiancee and I to enjoy to spend less time staring at screens when there's nothing to do outside.  This was one of the first games I picked up, as it was listed on nearly every blog/article on the topic of 2 player games.

However, it has ended up rarely being played.  It's fun, for what it is, and can end up just as competitive as chess if you both master the game.  But...we have so many other games that are more appealing this one just doesn't come out much.  It's a fun one to take to the park, in the car/plane, etc.  It's suitable for all ages, but it's not as much of a gateway game because it can be hard for new players to remember what each bug does - they'll need to consult the rules a lot which sometimes makes them frustrated.  I'd highly recommend this for anyone looking to entertain their kids on trips or for a small game to pack in a bag for traveling, but otherwise it sits on the shelf rarely getting used.

Original:
This is like a modular chess game.  It's easy to teach and plays through quick and simple.  The more often we play the better we get (and the longer our games take), but it definitely works as a gateway game too.

+ Mosquito
+ Pillbug

RATING: 10
One of the best board games I've ever played.  Plays anywhere, no setup, pure strategy/tactics with no luck, almost always takes under an hour (often much less).  Beautiful, virtually indestructible components and a unique theme; not that theme is the big draw here, but at least it isn't farming, war, or Cthulu.

Has a chessy feel due to the 'capture the main piece' win condition, but usually doesn't take as long, and this game hasn't been bludgeoned to death by computers yet either.  If you like abstracts and you don't own this game, you are doing it wrong.

With no setting up to do, the game begins when the first piece is placed down. As the subsequent pieces are placed this forms a pattern that becomes the playing surface (the pieces themselves become the board). Unlike other such games, the pieces are never eliminated and not all have to be played. The object of the game is to totally surround your opponent's queen, whilst at the same time trying to block your opponent from doing likewise to your queen. The player to totally surround his opponent's queen wins the game. I have the cool bakelite version. Expanded by Hive - The Mosquito

RATING: N/A
Hive is a highly addictive strategic game for two players that is not restricted by a board and can be played anywhere on any flat surface. Hive is made up of twenty two pieces, eleven black and eleven white, resembling a variety of creatures each with a unique way of moving.\13\ \13\
With no setting up to do, the game begins when the first piece is placed down. As the subsequent pieces are placed this forms a pattern that becomes the playing surface (the pieces themselves become the board). Unlike other such games, the pieces are never eliminated and not all have to be played. The object of the game is to totally surround your opponent's queen, while at the same time trying to block your opponent from doing likewise to your queen. The player to totally surround his opponent's queen wins the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.75
The best part about this game is its portability. My Significant Other and I like to bring it along if we know our destination involves a substantial wait. All that is required to get a game going is a flat surface.

The game design is simple and the rules are extremely easy to understand, yet the possibilities are infinite and the strategy involved reasonably deep. It is quite amazing that so much thought can be packed into so few tiles.

If there is a ranking for boardgames in terms of fun factor per unit of gaming equipment, then Hive will be No. 1.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]TRULY EXCELLENT.[/b]

Deep, quick, brain-burner of a game. A board-less affair with chesslike maneuvring, and heaps of continual jockeying for optimum position.
Hive is virtually unknown outside the grand halls of the gaming cognisenti, which is a gargantuan disgrace. I try to spread the gospel of Hive everywhere I go, reaching out to orphans and offering them hexagonal beetles...

On first playing this, my group started a winner-stays-on thing around the table. I took to the game like a duck to water, and ended up playing continually. No one could beat me... that night or ever. The glove is down.
I have the fantastic bakelite edition, and had to ship it from Germany to get it. Why didn't a British distributor grab this with both greedy paws? Who knows the minds of these clay-pipe smoking merchants? Not little old me.

Back to the game! Hive looks great and plays better. Simple to learn, difficult to master. How many more soundbites can I squeeze into my ramblings about this game? Quite a truckload more, I should say!
My GF hates it - playing with insects switches her mind right off! Then again, she likes Scooby Doo Monopoly.

I discover a new play, or strategy, every single time I play this wonderful game.
Hive works beautifully as a travel game or as a sit-down game at home. The feel of the heavy pieces is also a PERFECT geek pleasure. Yeah, baby.
The only thing I would have done differently to the designer: changed the powers of the beetle and the spider around. No joke.
What! Why do that?
Because it makes more sense for a spider to pin other bugs. Plus, spiders are cooler insects. Period.

Some people seem to have trouble remembering the specific powers of each bug - don't play with these losers. Play instead with someone who loves gaming as much as me!

[b]STRATEGY TIPS:[/b]

1.Remember that the queen can move too - some folks leave her stranded!
2.Use your ants - they are the most versatile piece, and your saviour/destroyer.
3.Use the beetle to enable placing of your own pieces about her - this is just gravy!
4.Try to pin your opponent's pieces when they have formed "arms".
5. Sometimes the hive will form 2 "arms" that are almost touching - use this to your advantage: move pieces across the divide, if advantageous.
6. NEVER give up! There's always a killer move you could make, you only have to look harder...

I could play this marvellous little game until the cows came home.. had tea and scones, and run a bath.

RATING: 7
This is a GREAT game and very fun!

I was actually surprised with this one.  I usually read many reviews before making a game purchase and have a pretty good idea what gameplay will be like, but this one turned out different than what I expected.  It is actually better.

Many reviews state that this game is light and an excellent filler; however, there is so much more going on here. Players must pay close attention to their opponent's moves while planning out their own route to victory.  This is more difficult than it sounds, especially if you have a skilled and competitive opponent.

I recommend this excellent game to everyone!  It should be a must addition to every board game collection!

RATING: 8.5
A very good game that is short to play and easy to teach, yet deep in strategic play. It is all about pinning, blocking and moving. 

Beware that the white player is having the advantage to begin and set up a strategy, while the black player reacts and tries to get the initiative. 

Good game to take outside , you can play it in the grass, sand, on vacation etc.
